articles.headline: The ‘No More Tears’ Shampoo, Now With No Formaldehyde
articles.snippet: Johnson & Johnson’s Baby Shampoo no longer contains two potentially harmful chemicals, formaldehyde and 1,4-dioxane, that have come under increasing scrutiny by consumers.
articles.abstract: Johnson & Johnson’s Baby Shampoo no longer contains two potentially harmful chemicals, formaldehyde and 1,4-dioxane, that have come under increasing scrutiny by consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SKILLMAN, N.J. — The only hint that something is different inside millions of bottles of Johnson’s Baby Shampoo arriving on store shelves are two words: “Improved Formula.”

articles.headline: Dangers of Giving In to Impulse for Revenge
articles.snippet: The New Jersey traffic jam scandal offers lessons on seeking retaliation for perceived slights.
articles.abstract: The New Jersey traffic jam scandal offers lessons on seeking retaliation for perceived slights.
articles.lead_paragraph: I found the machinations in the Netflix political series “House of Cards” to be immensely entertaining but a little over the top — until, that is, the traffic jam scandal in New Jersey.

articles.headline: Doctor Tells of Leaking Data to ‘Friend’ at SAC
articles.snippet: Sidney Gilman, an 81-year-old doctor, took the stand for the first time as the central witness for prosecutors in the trial of Mathew Martoma, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors.
articles.abstract: Sidney Gilman, an 81-year-old doctor, took the stand for the first time as the central witness for prosecutors in the trial of Mathew Martoma, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The largest insider trading scheme on record started with an attempt at friendship.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Weighing the Need for a Landline in a Cellphone World
articles.snippet: Questions to consider include the state of wireless 911 service, what happens when the power goes out and consumer protections.
articles.abstract: Questions to consider include the state of wireless 911 service, what happens when the power goes out and consumer protections.
articles.lead_paragraph: As I was hooking up a new phone in my living room, the kind where you plug a jack into the wall, I wondered why I was holding onto what had largely become a relic. It rarely rings, and even when it does, it’s usually the dentist or a robocaller.

articles.headline: Yahoo’s No. 2 Executive Made More Than His Boss (and Virtually Everyone Else)
articles.snippet: Henrique de Castro, who was fired this week as Yahoo’s No. 2 executive, will walk away with as much as $109 million for 15 months of work. His pay for 2012 was higher than that of most Silicon Valley chief executives.
articles.abstract: Henrique de Castro, who was fired this week as Yahoo’s No. 2 executive, will walk away with as much as $109 million for 15 months of work. His pay for 2012 was higher than that of most Silicon Valley chief executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:57 p.m. | Clarified that Mr. de Castro has not responded to requests for comment on his departure.

articles.headline: Resisting Mobile Hurts Nintendo’s Bottom Line
articles.snippet: The game maker admitted that it stumbled and said that instead of an annual profit of $527 million, it would report a net loss of $240 million.
articles.abstract: The game maker admitted that it stumbled and said that instead of an annual profit of $527 million, it would report a net loss of $240 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Nintendo has peered into its future, and the picture isn’t pretty.

articles.headline: After Leaving Office, Bloomberg Is More Hands-On at Old Company
articles.snippet: Michael R. Bloomberg’s dive back into the news side of Bloomberg L.P. has worried some that the division’s editorial independence could be called into question.
articles.abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg’s dive back into the news side of Bloomberg L.P. has worried some that the division’s editorial independence could be called into question.
articles.lead_paragraph: At editorial meetings in Bloomberg L.P.’s headquarters this week, Michael R. Bloomberg gave clear signs that he would not be taking a hands-off approach as he returned to his old company.

articles.headline: A Sneaky Path Into Target Customers’ Wallets
articles.snippet: An examination by The New York Times into an enormous data theft shows that Target’s system was particularly vulnerable to attack.
articles.abstract: An examination by The New York Times into an enormous data theft shows that Target’s system was particularly vulnerable to attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was, in essence, a cybercriminal’s dream.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris, Nicole Perlroth, Nathaniel Popper and Hilary Stout

articles.headline: In Keeping Grip on Data Pipeline, Obama Does Little to Reassure Industry
articles.snippet: While President Obama bolstered some protections for citizens, he did nothing, at least yet, to address the data security concerns of U.S. technology companies.
articles.abstract: While President Obama bolstered some protections for citizens, he did nothing, at least yet, to address the data security concerns of U.S. technology companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Google, which briefly considered moving all of its computer servers out of the United States last year after learning how they had been penetrated by the National Security Agency, was looking for a public assurance from President Obama that the government would no longer secretly suck data from the company’s corner of the Internet cloud.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Inspecting a Student Loan Spigot
articles.snippet: ITT Educational Services, which operates for-profit technical schools, has drawn the attention of regulators over a private lending trust.
articles.abstract: ITT Educational Services, which operates for-profit technical schools, has drawn the attention of regulators over a private lending trust.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few days after Christmas, ITT Educational Services, one of the nation’s largest operators of for-profit technical schools, reported some unwelcome news. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau had warned the company that it might seek penalties and remedies against it for possible student loan violations.

articles.headline: Yahoo’s Asian Lifeline
articles.snippet: Despite the company’s recent shake-up, Wall Street still likes its valuable holdings in China and Japan.
articles.abstract: Despite the company’s recent shake-up, Wall Street still likes its valuable holdings in China and Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s core business has been eroding. It’s lost ground in display advertising and in online search, and the Wall Street consensus is that its revenue declined last year.

articles.headline: Eagle Scout. Idealist. Drug Trafficker?
articles.snippet: Friends call Ross Ulbricht sensitive and soulful. Prosecutors contend that he ran a global, illicit online bazaar.
articles.abstract: Friends call Ross Ulbricht sensitive and soulful. Prosecutors contend that he ran a global, illicit online bazaar.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ross Ulbricht’s last moments as a free man were noisy enough to draw a crowd. Employees at the Glen Park branch of the San Francisco library heard a crashing sound and rushed to the science fiction section, expecting to find a patron had hit the floor. Instead, they found a handful of federal agents surrounding a slender 29-year-old man with light brown hair and wearing a T-shirt and jeans.

articles.headline: Chemical Spill Muddies Picture in a State Wary of Regulations
articles.snippet: West Virginia, with its strong ties to coal and chemicals, has long had a fierce opposition to environmental regulations.
articles.abstract: West Virginia, with its strong ties to coal and chemicals, has long had a fierce opposition to environmental regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Here in West Virginia, residents were still reeling from the chemical spill that left more than 300,000 people without usable water for days, many of them still frightened and unsure whether official assurances that they could once again drink tap water or bathe their children were true.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel, Michael Wines and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: Region Boiling, Israel Takes Up Castle Strategy
articles.snippet: As Israel faces threats both from traditional Shiite adversaries like Iran and from extremist Sunni cells in Syria, Iraq and beyond, officials insist they have no inclination to intervene.
articles.abstract: As Israel faces threats both from traditional Shiite adversaries like Iran and from extremist Sunni cells in Syria, Iraq and beyond, officials insist they have no inclination to intervene.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After a Katyusha rocket fired from Lebanon landed in Israel last month, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu blamed Hezbollah, the Shiite militia, and its Iranian backers. But Israeli security officials attributed the attack, as well as a similar one in August, to a Sunni jihadist group linked to Al Qaeda.

articles.headline: A Tiny Antenna Threatens the TV Networks’ Airspace
articles.snippet: Chet Kanojia’s company, Aereo, has figured out how to grab over-the-air television signals and stream them to subscribers on the Internet. It is an invention that could topple TV titans.
articles.abstract: Chet Kanojia’s company, Aereo, has figured out how to grab over-the-air television signals and stream them to subscribers on the Internet. It is an invention that could topple TV titans.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the case of American Broadcasting Companies v. Aereo comes before the Supreme Court in April, it will feature two American archetypes in a battle that could upend the television industry.

articles.headline: Publisher Struggles in Chase for Growth
articles.snippet: Aaron Kushner, publisher of The Orange County Register, has been playing hardball against distressed competitors and lustily grabbing for a bigger footprint.
articles.abstract: Aaron Kushner, publisher of The Orange County Register, has been playing hardball against distressed competitors and lustily grabbing for a bigger footprint.
articles.lead_paragraph: Timing matters when it comes to news. I had been reading about Aaron Kushner’s audacious strategy to invest in journalism ever since he bought The Orange County Register in 2012 for about $50 million and the assumption of $110 million in pension obligations. After years of covering layoffs, I wanted to write a different kind of tale about newspapers.

articles.headline: Juveniles Facing Lifelong Terms Despite Rulings
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court acted in 2010 and 2012 to curtail the use of mandatory life sentences for juveniles, but experts say most states have taken half-measures to carry out the rulings.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court acted in 2010 and 2012 to curtail the use of mandatory life sentences for juveniles, but experts say most states have taken half-measures to carry out the rulings.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — In decisions widely hailed as milestones, the United States Supreme Court in 2010 and 2012 acted to curtail the use of mandatory life sentences for juveniles, accepting the argument that children, even those who are convicted of murder, are less culpable than adults and usually deserve a chance at redemption.

articles.headline: U.N. Invites Iran to Syria Talks, Raising Objections From the U.S.
articles.snippet: American officials appeared to be caught off guard by the announcement and suggested that Iran had not met all the conditions for attending the conference to end the war in Syria.
articles.abstract: American officials appeared to be caught off guard by the announcement and suggested that Iran had not met all the conditions for attending the conference to end the war in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: The announcement by Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, that he had invited Iran to a peace conference to end the war in Syria drew strong objections on Sunday from American officials, who suggested that Iran had not met all the conditions for attending and that the invitation might need to be withdrawn.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: A Loophole Allows Lawmakers to Reel In Trips and Donations
articles.snippet: Weekend fund-raisers at high-end resorts prove well worth the trip for the members of Congress who host the events, and those seeking influence in Washington.
articles.abstract: Weekend fund-raisers at high-end resorts prove well worth the trip for the members of Congress who host the events, and those seeking influence in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — After some time in the hot tub, an evening cocktail reception and a two-and-a-half-hour dinner in a private dining room named Out of Bounds, Representative Adrian Smith, Republican of Nebraska, made one last stop, visiting the lounge at the Four Seasons Resort hotel here to spend more time with the lobbyists and other donors who had jetted in from Washington, D.C., to join him for the weekend getaway.

articles.headline: Iraq Again Uses Sunni Tribesmen in Militant War
articles.snippet: As the prime minister struggles to put down an insurgency led by Qaeda-affiliated militants, he has taken to paying tribal militias to fight as proxies, as the Americans did in 2007.
articles.abstract: As the prime minister struggles to put down an insurgency led by Qaeda-affiliated militants, he has taken to paying tribal militias to fight as proxies, as the Americans did in 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — At a command center in western Anbar Province, Iraqi military officials are handing out guns and cash to local Sunni tribal fighters who are battling militants for control of Iraq’s largest province.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Building Toward the Home of Tomorrow
articles.snippet: The announcement last week that Google was paying $3 billion to acquire Nest, a maker of Internet-connected home products, put a sort of Good Housekeeping seal of approval on this nascent market.
articles.abstract: The announcement last week that Google was paying $3 billion to acquire Nest, a maker of Internet-connected home products, put a sort of Good Housekeeping seal of approval on this nascent market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The home of the future — complete with helper bots and automated appliances — has long been the stuff of science fiction. The tech world is determined to make it a reality.

articles.headline: Debate on Photo Retouching Flares Online, With Roles Reversed
articles.snippet: A call for untouched photos of Lena Dunham from the new issue of Vogue had some wondering about the target and the far different terrain women’s magazines cover nowadays.
articles.abstract: A call for untouched photos of Lena Dunham from the new issue of Vogue had some wondering about the target and the far different terrain women’s magazines cover nowadays.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, two publications that consider themselves champions of women faced off — with an unexpected outcome.

articles.headline: Swindlers Use Telephones, With Internet’s Tactics
articles.snippet: Online phone-call tools have made it easy for swindlers to dupe victims out of valuable personal information or to overwhelm phone systems for essential public services like hospitals.
articles.abstract: Online phone-call tools have made it easy for swindlers to dupe victims out of valuable personal information or to overwhelm phone systems for essential public services like hospitals.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Phone swindles are practically as old as the telephone itself. But new technology has led to an onslaught of Internet-inspired fraud tactics that try to use telephone calls to dupe millions of people or to overwhelm switchboards for essential public services, causing deep concern among law enforcement and other groups.

articles.headline: Talks Over Syria Are Set to Begin, but Iran Is Not Invited
articles.snippet: Under pressure from the United States, Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, rescinded Iran’s invitation to the meeting a day after he offered it.
articles.abstract: Under pressure from the United States, Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, rescinded Iran’s invitation to the meeting a day after he offered it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American and other Western diplomats on Monday managed to salvage the long-awaited peace conference on Syria, which had seemed on the verge of unraveling before it even began when Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, issued an unexpected invitation to Iran to attend.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Anne Barnard
